explanation: To determine whether lfs_dir_compact violates the MISRA rule banning direct or indirect self-calls, the analysis needs the code (or call relationships) for every function it may call and every function transitively reachable from those callees so we can detect any path back to lfs_dir_compact. The list includes: - Direct callees of lfs_dir_compact (e.g. lfs_dir_needsrelocation, lfs_pair_cmp, lfs_bd_erase, lfs_tole32, lfs_dir_commitprog, lfs_fromle32, lfs_dir_traverse, lfs_pair_isnull, lfs_pair_tole32, lfs_dir_commitattr, lfs_pair_fromle32, lfs_gstate_xor, lfs_dir_getgstate, lfs_gstate_iszero, lfs_gstate_tole32, lfs_dir_commitcrc, lfs_pair_swap, lfs_cache_drop, lfs_alloc) — each is required because lfs_dir_compact calls it directly and any of them could (directly or via their callees) call back into lfs_dir_compact. - Transitive callees discovered from those direct callees (e.g. lfs_bd_prog, lfs_crc, lfs_tag_dsize, lfs_bd_read, lfs_frombe32, lfs_tag_id, lfs_tag_type3, lfs_tag_size, lfs_tobe32, lfs_dir_get, lfs_gstate_fromle32, lfs_alignup, lfs_min, lfs_bd_crc, lfs_fcrc_tole32, lfs_bd_sync, lfs_alloc_scan) — each is required because it is invoked (directly or indirectly) by a direct callee; we must inspect them to determine whether any call chain leads back to lfs_dir_compact (i.e., an indirect recursive cycle).
